description: A later produced and substantially shortened version of Imperial Russia’s original service rifle, this variant of the Mosin features a notably more compact barrel and an integral side-folding bayonet.  Produced during the latter days of the Second World War for the Soviet Union, the weapon exhibits less overall stopping power than its full-length older brother thanks to the former’s stubbier barrel.  Despite the arm being somewhat weaker than its forefather, the 7.62x54mm round that it chambers still packs a hefty punch, whilst its smaller size helps to make the weapon wieldier.

variants.description: The Model 44 is the carbine-sized variant of the standard 1891/30.  It has a shorter barrel, making it weaker than the 1891/30, but easier to carry.  This weapon also comes with an integrated side-folding bayonet.
This carbine packs the classic Mosin-Nagant Model 44 action in a modern-day stock capable of accepting modifications.

description: Developed by the Russian Empire prior to the onset of the First World War, the Mosin is a bolt-action military battle rifle chambered for 7.62x54mm rounds.  Powerful, unwieldy, and prolific across the world as military surplus, this sizable rifle is a Soviet updated version of the venerable Mosin.

variants.description: The Mosin-Nagant 1891/30 is a bolt-action, internal magazine-fed military rifle, developed by the Russian Empire and later used and perfected by the Soviet Union.
This Mosin-Nagant has exchanged the classic wooden stock for a modern synthetic model, carefully balanced to the same weight and handling, to allow support for modern accessories.

description: The Dragunov, developed for the Soviet military during the Cold War, was a marksmen’s rifle that fired the 7.62x54mm cartridge and was in service from 1965 until contemporary times.  The Dragunov is a dependable and tough combat precision rifle that will almost certainly bring out the sniper stalker in you, even if you aren't likely to be in Eastern Europe anytime soon.

variants.description: Often mislabeled a sniper rifle, the SVD Dragunov was one of the world’s first purpose-built marksmen’s weapons.  Produced by the Soviet Union during the Cold War and originally fielded in 1965, the SVD prompted a number of copycat designs to be produced for the armies of various other nations, namely China and Iraq.  The weapon is tough, reliable, and sufficiently accurate for long-range squad support, and it became a well-regarded precision rifle across eastern Europe.  Like most other communist armaments, the Dragunov was a quite rare find in the US collector’s market, though its semi-automatic design made it a more feasible import than its automatic brethren.
